translation: Ben MUST be swimming
comment: Hazu = reading where there is not actually entailment.

translation: Ben MUST be swimming
comment: Nichigainai slightly stronger => has to be the case based on what you know.

words: Booru-wa 	C 	ni 	aru 	hazu 	da
gloss: Ball-Top         C         Loc         exist         MOD         Cop
translation: it MUST be in C
it MUST be in C
Ann SHOULD be at the lake right now.

words: Meari-wa         ie-ni                 iru         hazu-da         ga,         tashika-de-wa                 nai
gloss: Mary-Top         house-Loc         exist         MOD-Cop         but         certain-Cop-Top         Neg
translation: Mary SHOULD be at home, but it’s not certain.
Mary SHOULD be at home
He MIGHT be coming to school today.
comment:
‘It is not known whether…’ (lit.)
As long as there is a possibility, kamoshirenai can be used.

words: Neko-wa         ie-no                 naka-ni         iru         kamoshirenai-shi                 i-nai         kamoshirenai
gloss: cat-Top         house-Gen         inside-Loc         exist         MOD-ConjunctiveParticle         exist-Neg  MOD
translation: The cat may be inside. The cat may also be outside.
It is not certain whether Mary is at home.
It is not certain whether Mary is at home.
it MUST NOT / CAN’T be in C.
it MUST NOT / CAN’T be in C.
You MUST wear a helmet.
comment: (lit.) if you don’t wear a helmet, then you’re not allowed (kind of). Meaning not transparent to native speakers => unit means deontic necessity.

translation: Visitors MUST leave by 6pm.
It would be better to wear formal clothes
It would be better to wear formal clothes
comment: No specific one to one correspondence to Eng. ‘ought to’.

translation: You MAY enter.
You MAY enter.
You can stay overnight and you can go home.
comment: Yo not necessary to interpretation of deontic possibility; more of a marker of new information.

translation: I DON’T HAVE TO / NEEDN’T wear formal clothes.
You are not allowed to ride a bike without a helmet
You are not allowed to ride a bike without a helmet
comment: Naranai has already appeared in deontic necessity; different way of using the verb nar. Up to linguist how to analyze this. If broken down into morphemes, then parallels can be seen between deontic necessity and deontic impossibility.

translation: You should not ride a bike without a helmet.
comment: beki => can also be used to express deontic weak necessity.

translation: you HAVE TO take this road.
We HAVE TO order from Gino’s
comment: [in principle possible but consultant finds it quite strong]

translation: We HAVE TO order from Gino’s
To get to the shopping centre, you SHOULD take the bus.
comment: feeling that beki is slightly less natural in teleological contexts as opposed to deontic contexts (more felicitous in deontic contexts). Beki more about rules than goals (intuition).

translation: To get to the shopping centre, you SHOULD take the bus.

translation: If you are buying a new shirt, you should come to my shop.

words: #        atarashii        syatsu-o         kau-nara                 watashi-no        mise-ni    kita-hoo-ga-ii                        yo
gloss: new                 shirt-Acc         buy-Conditional         1sg-Gen        shop-Dat  come-Direction-Nom-good 	Particle
comment: Option with hooga ii seems a bit strange; felicitous only if there are other alternatives explicit in the context. Basically a comparative construction.

translation: You CAN take way 1.
You CAN take way 1.
We CAN go to the swimming pool to the west.
you DON’T NEED TO / NEEDN’T do so.
you CAN’T take another road.
you CAN’T take another road.
Team A CAN’T lose to Team B.
I HAVE to sneeze
the water MUST come out from the right output.
comment: Difference between inanimate subject and first-person subject case in terms of modals chosen. When you use hazu = observation of what logically follows from what you know about the situation/context (intuition)

translation: duku trees CAN grow here.
Amy CAN make traditional Italian pasta
Amy CAN make traditional Italian pasta
Ben CAN walk now.
Travel vans CAN fit 20 people.
Travel vans CAN fit 20 people.

the water CAN’T come out from the left output.

I WANT/NEED TO buy it.
